posts.name: Jay Ticku
posts.cooked:
In order to send the current pose of the robot to the Field2d widget in Shuffleboard, my team wants to use the register_telemetry function in the Phoenix6 Swerve Drive API, as shown in the example in the SwerveWithPathPlanner from Phoenix6. However, when trying to use the register_telemetry function, we keep running into a Fatal Python error: Segmentation fault error on macOS or a Windows access violation on windows. Here is the stack trace, with sensitive information removed (“/Users/{user}” removed):

This error occurred when we modified the telemetry function to use the Field2d widget to send the pose of the robot. Furthermore, the error persisted when defaulting to using the original example code. The stack trace provided above is the error from using the original example code on macOS.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: It would help a lot if you could share your code. In particular, we need to see what’s at line 113 of telemetry.py .

posts.name: Jay Ticku
posts.cooked:
I was originally getting this error with the modified code I was using from the example but the stack trace I shared was from using the example telemetry code found on GitHub from Phoenix6. Here is the example telemetry file code from phoenix6:

This is the code that originally caused me the error:

The only difference between the stack trace that I provided earlier for the example code and my modified code is that the stack trace showed an unknown line causing the error:

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: That looks like it’s just pytest failing, I would expect that actually running the code works as expected. There’s a known issue in Python where object cleanup can happen in a weird order that causes a segfault on program shutdown, as the native swerve odometry thread isn’t always shut down in time when the other Python objects are cleaned up. This issue appears to be worse when multiple tests are run in parallel. But since that only affects program shutdown (and as far as I can tell it only affects tests), it shouldn’t affect your ability to run the program.

posts.name: Jay Ticku
posts.cooked: I would have to confirm this on Tuesday when testing with the robot, but if I can remember correctly, I remember when deploying and running the code with the tests failing, there still seemed to be another error. When looking at the network tables on Shuffleboard, I would see the creation of the field table, showing that the init function of the telemetry object is running, but I don’t remember seeing the actual pose of the robot updating, possibly signifying that the telemetry method is not running. I would have to confirm this on Tuesday, but could this mean that the Odometry Thread is not running?

posts.name: Michael Fisher
posts.cooked:
I’m encountering this exact crash.  Unfortunately, some of us actually want to run Unit tests, and for good reason.  I get this segmentation fault from a freshly generated Tuner X project.

Any way to just skip this section of code in tests?  Does robotpy have an equivalent of is_running_tests() , I didn’t see anything like this in the docs.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: Something we haven’t tried yet that might fix the issue is the new isolated test mode , so you can try enabling that.

link_counts.title: Please try pyfrc's new isolated test mode

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Jay Ticku
posts.cooked: Interestingly, the error seemed to self resolve over time. I ended up removing it and then a couple of weeks later when I added it back in, it seemed to fix itself. Some of the most significant changes I made that could have fixed the error were that I upgraded my python version to 3.13.2, used isolated test mode, registered the telemetry callback in subsystem init, and made sure I was using the latest robotpy version. However, the tests still pass even when not using isolated mode. Most likely the python version resulted in the fix.
